newsitem.title: USA: New junk and trust prfd supply to hit US corp mart.
newsitem.headline: New junk and trust prfd supply to hit US corp mart.

text.p: Attracted by strong buyside demand and cheap market rates, issuers are preparing several junk bonds and trust preferred stock offerings for Friday and the following week, syndicate officials said.
The market was abuzz with talk of a $700 million investment-grade corporate bond offering from Sherwin-Williams Co via Salomon Brothers Inc expected for next week.

Market sources say the company will sell $100 million of three-year bonds, $100 million of five-year bonds and $200 million of 10-year bonds in a public deal. Details on the remainder, which will be sold privately, were not available.
New investment-grade bond issuance on Friday is expected to consist primarily of trust preferred stock offerings. Deals expected include:

-A $150 million offering by BanPonce, a Puerto Rican bank holding company, of 30-year trust preferreds, non-callable in 10-years, via Credit Suisse First Boston. Price talk is around 145 basis points market sources said.

-A $200 million offering by Bankers Trust Co of 40-year trust preferred securities, non callable in five years, via Smith Barney Inc. The offering of $25 par value shares is primarily targeting retail investors.
Junk bond issuance is also expected to be active.
Globalstar LP plans to debut in the high-yield market in the coming weeks with a 144a offering of $250 million in senior notes due 2004, sources say. Lehman Brothers will be the underwriter.
The company is a building a network of low-earth orbit satellites that will provide mobile telephone service to users all over the world. The system is expected to be completed in late 1998.
Loral Space & Communications Ltd holds a major equity stake in the company.
New junk deals expected on Friday include:
-TV Azteca's $400 million 144A in seven- and 10-year debt via a Bear Stearns & Co syndicate.
-Advanced Radio Telecom Corp's $125 million 10-year senior notes through Merrill Lynch & Co Inc. The issue is expected to be an overfunded cash pay deal priced with warrants.
